Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility, state protection, and delay in claiming refugee status
Crimes.Application_Facts: Myle worked in Canada for four years without a work permit while fearing return to St. Vincent due to domestic abuse
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Initial rejection by Refugee Protection Division
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Federal Court remanded the case for reconsideration
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Worked without authorization while awaiting refugee determination
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Domestic abuse and lack of state protection in St. Vincent
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Trauma, lack of awareness, and psychological evidence
Crimes.Applicable_Legislation: IRPA, sections related to refugee protection and admissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Insufficient reasoning on credibility and delay
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board failed to provide clear reasons for rejecting credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Testimony, psychological reports, country condition documents
Crimes.Application_Basis: Fear of persecution due to domestic violence
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Personal testimony, corroborative evidence, expert reports
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Refugee protection and work authorization retroactively
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Credibility must be assessed with clear reasons; delays require contextual analysis
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to address psychological evidence and country conditions
Crimes.Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by a different panel
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Risk of re-victimization upon return to St. Vincent
Crimes.Cause_Description: Domestic abuse and lack of police protection in home country
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of IRB and Federal Court
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Errors in credibility, state protection, and delay assessment
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to consider mitigating factors for delay
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court

Crimes.Crime_Name: Border document misrepresentation (if applicable based on suppressed fragments)
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Alleged misrepresentation in entry or application documents
Crimes.Procedural_Context: Judicial review of refugee claim denial
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned credibility without addressing corroboration
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, country condition reports, psychological evidence
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of domestic abuse and threats in St. Vincent
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to assess credibility with proper reasoning
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Psychological reports and country condition evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Clear reasons required for adverse credibility findings
Crimes.Application_Factor: Delayed claim due to trauma and lack of knowledge
Crimes.Cause_of_Refusal: Perceived lack of credibility and unexplained delay
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to analyze lack of state protection and trauma effects
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness: Insufficient opportunity to respond to credibility concerns
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged omission or misrepresentation at border or in application
Crimes.Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Trauma and lack of awareness as explanation for inconsistencies
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Focus: Canadian immigration law and international refugee obligations
Crimes.Relevant_Law: IRPA, Refugee Convention, Charter of Rights
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Lack of detailed reasoning on key determinations
Crimes.Omission_Type: Failure to disclose or explain timeline discrepancies

Crimes.Crime_Name: Domestic abuse (as described, potentially involving Assault or Criminal Harassment under the Criminal Code)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee protection based on gender-based persecution
Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Repeated abuse, threats to life, lack of police response
Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Survivor’s efforts to seek help and escape
Crimes.Criminality_Severity: High – credible threat to life and safety
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Supported by testimony and psychological evaluation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal testimony, medical/psychological reports, country condition reports
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk of re-victimization if returned
Crimes.Risk_Nature: State inability or unwillingness to protect
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Yes – based on gender and relationship
Crimes.Jurisdiction: International refugee law, Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 96 – definition of Convention refugee
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Claim initially rejected, remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court intervened due to legal errors
Crimes.Legal_Procedure: Refugee appeal and federal court review
Crimes.Review_Mechanism: Judicial review under Federal Courts Act

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to apply for refugee protection in a timely manner
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Impact of delay on credibility and eligibility
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Delay used to质疑 credibility without proper analysis
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimony, pastoral support evidence, psychological reports
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of domestic abuse in St. Vincent
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Trauma and lack of awareness as mitigating factors
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider trauma and external assistance
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Pastor’s role, trauma impact, NGO support
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Delay must be examined with context and compassion
Crimes.Application_Factor: Four-year gap between arrival and claim
Crimes.Outcome_of_Review: Case sent back to new panel
Crimes.Cause_of_Refusal: Unsubstantiated concern over delay affecting credibility
Crimes.Legal_Defense_or_Challenge: Trauma and lack of legal knowledge as defense
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Lack of substantiated reasoning on delay
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Potential loss of eligibility due to delay
